    Background

    Description of the condition

    Primary vesicoureteric reflux (VUR) is thought to be a maturational abnormality of the vesicoureteric junction, which results in retrograde passing of urine up the ureter during voiding. Although the exact prevalence is unknown, about a third of children investigated after a urinary tract infection (UTI), show evidence of VUR (Smellie 1994). UTI is common, affecting 5% to 10% of all children (Hellstrom 1991), with about 20% of them likely to suffer a recurrence (Smellie 1994, Panaretto 1999). VUR is thought to predispose children to UTI and renal involvement during a UTI can potentially cause permanent renal damage, possibly in up to 15% of patients (Montini 2007b). Retrospective analyses of selected individuals with renal scarring, have reported hypertension and chronic kidney disease (CKD) in approximately 20% and 10% respectively (Martinell 1996; Smellie 1998). However data from a prospective cohort study indicated that these adverse outcomes occur considerably less frequently (Wennerstrom 2000a; Wennerstrom 2000b).

    As a result of the hypothesized causal link between VUR and renal scarring, VUR screening and treatment strategies have largely been directed towards avoidance of UTI and therefore any subsequent renal damage (Belman 1995). Preventative treatments have included long‐term, low‐dose antibiotic, surgical correction, endoscopic injection and more recently alternative strategies such as cranberry products and probiotics, Surgical correction of VUR involves techniques such as Politano‐Leadbetter, Lich‐Gregoir and Cohen ureteral reimplantation and the less invasive endoscopic periureteric injection of bulking agents such as polydimethylsiloxane (Macroplastique), dextranomer/hyaluronic acid copolymer (Deflux) or glutaraldehyde cross‐linked bovine collagen (GAX) (Capozza 2002; Frankenschmidt 1997; Frey 1997; Oswald 2002). Although VUR is a common problem in childhood, there has been no consensus regarding the optimal management strategy and practice varies widely.

    Description of the intervention

    Interventions have included long‐term, low‐dose antibiotic treatment, primarily cotrimoxazole, trimethoprim or nitrofurantoin, for an average of 1.5 years, surgical correction using Poloitano‐Leadbetter, Cohen, Lich‐Gregoir or Glenn Anderson methods, endoscopic injection of various agents, probiotics, cranberry product, circumcision and oxybutynin,

    How the intervention might work

    Maintaining a constant low‐dose of antibiotic may prevent the overgrowth of pathogenic bacteria that cause a UTI, Surgery to reimplant the ureters should reduce the back flow of urine up the ureters toward the kidney and may reduce the likelihood of infection. Similarly endoscopic injection of an agent to elongate and weld the submucosal tract of the ureter could reduce backward flow of urine toward the kidneys, Cranberry products are thought to contain a substance that reduces the adhesion of bacteria to the bladder wall, reducing the likelihood of overgrowth of bacterial pathogens. Probiotics are thought to increase the number of beneficial bacteria in the body and reduce overgrowth of pathogenic organisms. Circumcision is thought to reduce the carriage of bacteria on the penis and thus reduce the likelihood that bacteria pass up the urethra causing an infection. An anticholinergic agent, such as oxybutynin, is used to treat unstable bladder to reduce symptoms of frequency, incontinence and urgency which may increase the risk of UTI.

    Why it is important to do this review

    Many treatment options are available for children with VUR to prevent recurring UTI and there is considerable variability in clinical practice worldwide, Identifying and analysing the available data on prophylactic treatment efficacy will guide the clinical care of children with VUR while also identifying evidence gaps for future focus.

    Objectives

    The aim of this review was to evaluate the available evidence for both benefits and harms of the currently available treatment options for primary VUR: operative, non‐operative or no intervention.

    Methods

    Criteria for considering studies for this review

    Types of studies

    Randomised controlled trials (RCTs) and quasi‐RCTs (RCTs in which allocation to treatment was obtained by alternation, use of alternate medical records, date of birth or other predictable methods) which evaluated any treatment for primary VUR were included.

    Types of participants

    Inclusion criteria

    Males and females of any age with primary VUR diagnosed by voiding cystourethrogram (VCUG), with or without UTI.

    Exclusion criteria

    Patients with VUR associated with posterior urethral valves, spina bifida, other urological abnormalities or kidney transplants.

    Types of interventions

    Treatments of VUR including surgery (open and endoscopic techniques), antibiotic prophylaxis of any duration, non‐invasive techniques such as bladder training, complementary medicines, and any combination of therapies.

    Types of outcome measures

    Primary outcomes

    • Number of patients with symptomatic UTI: defined as symptoms consistent with a UTI which may include local symptoms only e.g. dysuria or systemic symptoms such as fever, together with a positive urine culture. This outcome includes febrile UTI

    Secondary outcomes

    • Number of patients with UTI accompanied by fever (temperature > 38°C or > 100.4°F) (a subset of the data from the outcome symptomatic UTI)

    • Number of patients with at least one repeat positive urine culture during follow‐up

    • Renal parenchymal abnormality: defined as new, progression from pre‐existing damage, resolution, end‐stage kidney disease (ESKD) and diagnosed by ultrasound, intravenous pyelography (IVP) or 99mTc‐DMSA (dimercaptosuccinic acid) scintigraphy (DMSA scan)

    • Number of previously unaffected subjects who developed hypertension: defined as > 140 mmHg systolic, 90 mmHg diastolic for adults and above the 95th percentiles for systolic and diastolic blood pressures in children

    • Kidney function impairment: defined as a glomerular filtration rate (GFR) (measured either directly or calculated from serum creatinine (eGFR)) < 95th percentile for age, or a decrease in kidney function over the duration of the study

    • Correction or spontaneous resolution of VUR: defined as the number of children and/or ureters without VUR on follow up VCUG

    • Microbial resistance: obstruction following correction of VUR, death or serious injury resulting from the anaesthetic, wound infection, fever, adverse effects of medication including urticaria and gastro‐intestinal reaction.

    • Any reported adverse events (drug or surgery‐related)

    Search methods for identification of studies

    Electronic searches

    We searched the Cochrane Kidney and Transplant Specialised Register up to 3 May 2018 through contact with the Information Specialist using search terms relevant to this review. The Cochrane Kidney and Transplant Specialised Register contains studies identified from several sources.

    1. Monthly searches of the Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials (CENTRAL)

    2. Weekly searches of MEDLINE OVID SP

    3. Handsearching of kidney‐related journals and the proceedings of major kidney conferences

    4. Searching of the current year of EMBASE OVID SP

    5. Weekly current awareness alerts for selected kidney and transplant journals

    6. Searches of the International Clinical Trials Register (ICTRP) Search Portal & ClinicalTrials.gov.

    Studies contained in the Specialised Register are identified through search strategies for CENTRAL, MEDLINE, and EMBASE based on the scope of Cochrane Kidney and Transplant. Details of these strategies, as well as a list of handsearched journals, conference proceedings and current awareness alerts, are available in the Specialised Register section of information about Cochrane Kidney and Transplant.

    See Appendix 1 for search terms used in strategies for this review.

    Searching other resources

    1. Reference lists of review articles, relevant studies and clinical practice guidelines.

    2. Letters seeking information about unpublished or incomplete studies to investigators known to be involved in previous studies.

    Data collection and analysis

    Selection of studies

    For the first three versions of this review (Hodson 2007; Nagler 2011; Wheeler 2004) titles and abstracts obtained from the above searches were screened for selection independently by at least two authors. In all cases an overly inclusive selection was preferred to avoid losing relevant studies and to ensure additional studies could be identified from the reference lists. Where suitability was uncertain or no abstract available, the full article was obtained and screened by the same authors. Any disagreements were resolved by discussion with a third author. Authors were contacted to obtain raw or missing data where necessary. For the 2018 update a single author reviewed the titles.

    Data extraction and management

    For the 2004, 2007 and 2011 versions of this review data extraction was conducted independently by at least two authors, using a standardised data extraction form. All studies, reported in a non‐English journal, were translated prior to assessment. Any further information required from the original author was requested by written correspondence and any relevant information obtained in this manner was included in the review. Any disagreements were resolved by discussion with a third author. For the 2018 update, two authors extracted five studies and reviewed agreement; 84 of 90 fields were identical across authors so a single author extracted data from the remaining nine studies. Foreign language articles were translated using Google Translate.

    Assessment of risk of bias in included studies

    The following items were independently assessed by two authors using the risk of bias assessment tool (Higgins 2011) (seeAppendix 2). In 2018 two authors extracted data from five new studies and compared agreement. A consistent difference between authors was seen and corrected in the remaining studies that were extracted by a single author. Since all three authors are also authors on an included study (PRIVENT 2009), an independent researcher extracted risk of bias data for that study.

    • Was there adequate sequence generation?

    • Was allocation adequately concealed?

    • Was knowledge of the allocated interventions adequately prevented during the study?

    • Were incomplete outcome data adequately addressed?

    • Are reports of the study free of suggestion of selective outcome reporting?

    • Was the study apparently free of other problems that could put it at a risk of bias?

    Measures of treatment effect

    Dichotomous outcomes

    For dichotomous outcomes, the risk ratio (RR) and corresponding 95% confidence interval (CI) were chosen to describe the treatment effects and the precision of their point estimates. Number needed to treat (NNT) estimates were calculated to compare the benefits and harms of each active treatment.

    Continuous outcomes

    Where continuous scales of measurement were used to assess effects of treatment such as blood pressure and kidney function measured by eGFR, the mean difference (MD) and 95% CI was used. Where summary statistics were missing, they were derived from accompanying P values.

    Planned treatment comparisons

    • Antibiotics versus surgery or endoscopic treatment

    • Antibiotics versus placebo or no treatment

    • One antibiotic treatment versus another

    • Surgical or endoscopic correction with no other treatment

    • Any combinations of any active treatment

    Unit of analysis issues

    The unit of analysis for the primary and most secondary outcomes except resolution of reflux, was children only. For resolution of reflux, we included data for ureters as the unit of analysis and for microbial resistance, rates were expressed per UTI.

    Dealing with missing data

    Email contact was made to authors where there was missing data or methodology details. Responses were infrequent but Professor Jean Smellie provided additional details.

    Assessment of heterogeneity

    Heterogeneity between studies was analysed using the Cochran's Q statistic with the threshold for statistical significance set at alpha = 0.1 (Lau 1997). It was also tested by means of the I2 test, reflecting the percentage of total variation across studies that could be ascribed to heterogeneity (Higgins 2003). Due to an insufficient number of studies within each comparison group, formal evaluation of the different sources of heterogeneity was not possible.

    Assessment of reporting biases

    Publication bias was to be assessed using a funnel plot; there were insufficient studies to do so.

    Data synthesis

    A random effects model was used, with subsequent testing for robustness of the analysis by applying the fixed effect model.

    Subgroup analysis and investigation of heterogeneity

    Where there is sufficient data univariate analysis was to be used to explore whether the duration of antibiotic treatment, type of antibiotic, type of surgery and material used for endoscopic treatment have an effect on treatment efficacy. Heterogeneity was analysed using the Q statistic with a threshold for the P value of < 0.1 and the I2 test (Higgins 2003)

    Sensitivity analysis

    To determine the effect of study quality on the primary outcome's pooled summary measure, sensitivity and subgroup analysis was to be performed to examine the influence of design features on results but small numbers of studies and participants prevented this study.

    'Summary of findings' tables

    We presented the main results of the review in 'Summary of findings' tables. These tables present key information concerning the quality of the evidence, the magnitude of the effects of the interventions examined, and the sum of the available data for the main outcomes (Schünemann 2011a). The 'Summary of findings' tables also include an overall grading of the evidence related to each of the main outcomes using the GRADE (Grades of Recommendation, Assessment, Development and Evaluation) approach (GRADE 2008). The GRADE approach defines the quality of a body of evidence as the extent to which one can be confident that an estimate of effect or association is close to the true quantity of specific interest. The quality of a body of evidence involves consideration of within‐trial risk of bias (methodological quality), directness of evidence, heterogeneity, precision of effect estimates and risk of publication bias (Schünemann 2011b). We presented the following outcomes in the 'Summary of findings' tables.

    • UTI

      • Symptomatic UTI

      • Febrile UTI

      • Asymptomatic (repeat positive urine culture; afebrile UTI)

    • Renal parenchymal abnormality

    • Spontaneous resolution or surgical correction of VUR; persistent VUR

    • Adverse events

      • ESKD

      • Hypertension

      • Drug related (e.g. vomiting, rash, thrush)

      • Surgery related (e.g. ureteral obstruction, post‐operative pain)

    • Microbial resistance

    Results

    Description of studies

    Results of the search

    The first version of this review (Wheeler 2004) included 10 studies (BIRSG 1983; Capozza 2002; Frey 1997; Holland 1982; IRS USA 1992; IRS EUR 1981‐2003; Morris 1991; Oswald 2002; Reddy 1997; Smellie 2001) The International Reflux Study was reported in a European (IRS EUR 1981‐2003) and an American arm (IRS USA 1992) and these reports were treated as two separate studies. Two studies were published as abstracts in conference proceedings only (Morris 1991; Reddy 1997).

    The second version of this review (Hodson 2007), searched literature up to June 2006 and identified one new study (Garin 2006) along with two additional reports of the European arm of the International Reflux Study (IRS EUR 1981‐2003).

    A third update of this review (Nagler 2011) searched the literature up to August 2010 and included an additional nine studies (Craig 2002; Dite 2007; Lee 2007a; Montini 2008; Pennesi 2008; PRIVENT 2009; Roussey‐Kesler 2008; Scott 1968; Swedish Reflux Trial 2010). Craig 2002 was published only as an abstract and Dite 2007 was originally published in Czech and was translated before assessment. We also found two papers that belonged to previously included studies (IRS EUR 1981‐2003; IRS USA 1992). One ongoing study was identified (RIVUR 2008).

    The current update searched literature up to May 2018 and adds a further 14 studies (Ahn 2003; Dotis 2014; Espino Hernandez 2012; Garcia‐Aparicio 2013; Gucuk 2013; Habeeb Abid 2015; Hari 2015; Kojima 2012; Lee 2015; Moore 2014; Nordenstrom 2016; RIVUR 2008; Takvani 2015). Figure 1 details the study selection process and results.

    • Open in figure viewer
    Figure 1

    Study flow diagram.

    Included studies

    Thirty two of 34 studies included two study arms and two studies (Swedish Reflux Trial 2010; Reddy 1997) involved three comparisons.

    Antibiotic prophylaxis versus no treatment/placebo

    In eight studies (796 children) antibiotic treatment was compared with no treatment (Espino Hernandez 2012; Garin 2006; Montini 2008; Pennesi 2008; Reddy 1997; Roussey‐Kesler 2008; Swedish Reflux Trial 2010; Takvani 2015) and with placebo in four studies involving 984 children (Craig 2002; Hari 2015; PRIVENT 2009; RIVUR 2008). In Reddy 1997 no treatment was compared with two antibiotic prophylaxis regimens (daily or intermittent antibiotic administration). Nine of the 12 studies reported the outcome of repeat symptomatic UTI. In eight of the 12 studies, participants were recruited after at least one symptomatic UTI (Garin 2006; Hari 2015; Montini 2008; Pennesi 2008; PRIVENT 2009; RIVUR 2008; Roussey‐Kesler 2008; Swedish Reflux Trial 2010), in two studies children had not experienced a UTI but had VUR detected after antenatal ultrasonography (Craig 2002; Takvani 2015), and in two studies, details on prior UTI were not reported (Espino Hernandez 2012; Reddy 1997). Two studies included children with the entire spectrum of VUR grade (Craig 2002; PRIVENT 2009); two studies included children with grades I to IV (Hari 2015; RIVUR 2008); seven studies included various lower grades of VUR (Espino Hernandez 2012; Garin 2006; Montini 2008; Pennesi 2008; Roussey‐Kesler 2008; Swedish Reflux Trial 2010; Takvani 2015); and one study (Reddy 1997) did not report VUR grade details. Five studies did not report the gender of participating children (Craig 2002; Espino Hernandez 2012; Hari 2015; Reddy 1997; Takvani 2015) while in the remaining seven studies girls (990) outnumbered boys (331), with an extreme imbalance in RIVUR 2008 (558 girls to 49 boys). In three studies (Garin 2006; Montini 2008; PRIVENT 2009), the investigators included both children with and without VUR but for this review we included only the data from children with VUR. Antibiotic treatment duration ranged from one to three years, with the most common practice being one year (5 studies). Two studies did not report antibiotic duration (Espino Hernandez 2012; Takvani 2015)

    Adherence was addressed in six studies (Hari 2015, Montini 2008; Pennesi 2008; PRIVENT 2009; RIVUR 2008, Swedish Reflux Trial 2010).

    • Hari 2015 measured adherence by weighing returned medication bottles and compliance was reported as not different between the two treatment groups

    • Pennesi 2008 tested the urine samples of children that developed a febrile UTI for presence of the prophylactic drug. He found all patients were adherent.

    • Montini 2008 found 71% of participants were adherent when assessed by measuring antimicrobial activity in a sample of screened urine samples. The reported adherence rate was 86% according to the visual analogue questionnaire.

    • PRIVENT 2009 tested adherence by weighing the bottles at each clinic visit as well as by direct questioning of the parents. The authors reported no difference in the frequency of measured non‐adherence between the groups.

    • Swedish Reflux Trial 2010 report stated that adherence to the antibiotic prophylaxis had been assessed by asking questions during every follow‐up visit, but no findings were provided.

    • RIVUR 2008 measured adherence by collecting used and unused medication bottles, by direct questioning at clinic visits and patient diaries. 467 children were reported as being 75% compliant with medication while 91 children in the antibiotic group and 76 children in the placebo group stopped taking the medication. No significant difference between adherence rates across the two treatment groups was reported.

    Surgical reimplantation of the ureters

    In seven studies (815 children) the effectiveness of low‐dose antibiotic prophylaxis, given for one to five years, was compared with ureteric reimplantation by open surgery, using different surgical methods (BIRSG 1983; Holland 1982; IRS EUR 1981‐2003; IRS USA 1992; Morris 1991; Smellie 2001; Scott 1968). Only one study (IRS EUR 1981‐2003) reported the outcome of repeat symptomatic UTI, Five studies recruited children with at least one UTI while Morris 1991 did not report this detail. Three studies involved children with VUR of grades III and IV (IRS EUR 1981‐2003; IRS USA 1992; Morris 1991). One study (Smellie 2001) included children with grades III to V VUR, Holland 1982 included children with grades III to IV and BIRSG 1983 included children with grades II (with scarring) and III to V. Scott 1968 did not report VUR grades of participating children. IRS EUR 1981‐2003 and Holland 1982 did not report gender. A total of 368 girls and 144 boys were included in the remaining studies.

    Kojima 2012 compared two different surgical methods, reimplantation with and without advancement, for the outcomes of positive urine culture and correction of reflux. Children in the study had VUR grades I to V with 13 girls and 17 boys.

    Endoscopic injection treatment

    Four studies compared endoscopic subureteric injection of Deflux/Dexel (Capozza 2002; Dite 2007; Nordenstrom 2016, Swedish Reflux Trial 2010) with prophylactic antibiotic. Three of these (Dite 2007; Nordenstrom 2016; Swedish Reflux Trial 2010) reported the outcome of repeat symptomatic UTI. Four studies (Frey 1997; Habeeb Abid 2015; Moore 2014; Oswald 2002) compared different injection products, two of which were Deflux with Macroplastique (Oswald 2002; Moore 2014), and these studies reported on symptomatic UTI allowing for pooling of data. One study compared GAX 35 with GAX 65 (Frey 1997) and one study compared dextranomer/hyaluronic acid polymer with polyacrylate polyalcohol copolymer (Vantris) (Habeeb Abid 2015). One study compared endoscopic injection with surgical reimplantation of ureters (Garcia‐Aparicio 2013). Swedish Reflux Trial 2010 included a third arm of no treatment, within their study allowing a comparison between endoscopic injection and no treatment. Two of the four studies comparing endoscopic injection with antibiotics recruited the majority of their participating children after a UTI (Nordenstrom 2016; Swedish Reflux Trial 2010), none of the four studies comparing different endoscopic injection polymers detailed prior UTI history of the participating children and the study of endoscopic injection versus surgical reimplantation also did not report prior UTI history (Garcia‐Aparicio 2013). VUR grade was reported by eight of the nine studies, with only Habeeb Abid 2015 not reporting this detail. VUR grade ranged widely from all grades to a focus on high grades; III to V. Gender was reported in eight of the nine studies and showed an over representation of girls (445) compared to boys (225).

    Probiotics compared with low dose antibiotic treatment

    Two studies involving 248 children compared probiotics (Lactobacillus acidophilus) with antibiotic treatment, cotrimoxazole (Lee 2007a; Lee 2015) and one study of 85 children compared a combination of two strains of probiotic (Lactobacillus acidophilus and Bifidobacterium lactis) plus antibiotics (nitrofurantoin) with antibiotics alone (Mohseni 2013). The three studies reported VUR grade and covered the spectrum of grades from I to V while two of the three studies reported a prior history of UTI (Lee 2015; Mohseni 2013). There were 133 girls and 200 boys who participated.

    Other interventions

    A study of 76 children (53 girls and 23 boys), with grades I and II VUR and recruited after a previous UTI, compared cranberry capsules with no treatment (Dotis 2014). One study of 91 boys with one prior UTI and VUR grades I to III, compared antibiotics alone with antibiotics plus circumcision (Gucuk 2013). A study of 149 children, that did not report on grade of VUR, gender or UTI history, compared oxybutynin with placebo for the single outcome VUR resolution (Ahn 2003).

    Excluded studies

    We excluded 10 studies. See Characteristics of excluded studies.

    Risk of bias in included studies

    Four studies were considered at low risk of bias for all domains within the risk of bias tool (Craig 2002; Hari 2015; PRIVENT 2009; RIVUR 2008) and all compared low dose antibiotics with placebo. The remaining 30 studies ranged in quality with many study quality fields having a high risk of bias or unclear risk of bias.

    An overview is provided in Figure 2 and Figure 3.

    • Open in figure viewer
    Figure 2

    Methodological quality graph: review authors' judgements about each methodological quality item presented as percentages across all included studies.

    • Open in figure viewer
    Figure 3

    Methodological quality summary: review authors' judgements about each methodological quality item for each included study.

    Allocation

    Sequence generation

    The method of sequence generation was at a low risk of bias in 16 studies (Capozza 2002; Craig 2002; Garcia‐Aparicio 2013; Hari 2015; IRS EUR 1981‐2003; IRS USA 1992; Lee 2015; Mohseni 2013; Montini 2008; Nordenstrom 2016; Pennesi 2008; PRIVENT 2009; RIVUR 2008; Roussey‐Kesler 2008; Smellie 2001; Swedish Reflux Trial 2010), at high risk of bias in two studies (Lee 2007a; Scott 1968), and unclear risk in 16 studies (Ahn 2003; BIRSG 1983; Dite 2007; Dotis 2014; Espino Hernandez 2012; Frey 1997; Garin 2006; Gucuk 2013; Habeeb Abid 2015; Holland 1982; Kojima 2012; Moore 2014; Morris 1991; Oswald 2002; Reddy 1997; Takvani 2015).

    Allocation concealment

    Allocation concealment was at a low risk of bias in 12 studies (Capozza 2002; Craig 2002; Frey 1997; Hari 2015; IRS EUR 1981‐2003; IRS USA 1992; Montini 2008; Pennesi 2008; PRIVENT 2009; RIVUR 2008; Roussey‐Kesler 2008; Swedish Reflux Trial 2010), high risk of bias in three studies (Lee 2007a; Moore 2014; Scott 1968), and unclear risk in 19 studies (Ahn 2003; BIRSG 1983; Dite 2007; Dotis 2014; Espino Hernandez 2012; Garcia‐Aparicio 2013; Garin 2006; Gucuk 2013; Habeeb Abid 2015; Holland 1982; Kojima 2012; Lee 2015; Mohseni 2013; Morris 1991; Nordenstrom 2016; Oswald 2002; Reddy 1997; Smellie 2001; Takvani 2015).

    Blinding

    While it is understood blinding clinicians and participants/carers to a surgical procedure is not easily feasible, blinding of outcome assessment is feasible.

    Performance bias

    Risk of performance bias was low in five studies (Craig 2002; Frey 1997; Hari 2015; PRIVENT 2009; RIVUR 2008), high in 16 studies (BIRSG 1983; Capozza 2002; Dite 2007; Garin 2006; Holland 1982; IRS EUR 1981‐2003; IRS USA 1992; Lee 2007a; Lee 2015; Montini 2008; Morris 1991; Oswald 2002; Pennesi 2008; Scott 1968; Smellie 2001; Swedish Reflux Trial 2010), and unclear in 13 studies (Ahn 2003; Dotis 2014; Espino Hernandez 2012; Garcia‐Aparicio 2013; Gucuk 2013; Habeeb Abid 2015; Kojima 2012; Mohseni 2013; Moore 2014; Nordenstrom 2016; Reddy 1997; Roussey‐Kesler 2008; Takvani 2015).

    Detection bias

    Risk of detection bias was low in 12 studies (BIRSG 1983; Craig 2002; Frey 1997; Hari 2015; IRS EUR 1981‐2003; IRS USA 1992; Lee 2007a; Pennesi 2008; PRIVENT 2009; RIVUR 2008; Smellie 2001; Swedish Reflux Trial 2010); high in four studies (Capozza 2002; Lee 2015; Montini 2008; Scott 1968), and unclear in 18 studies (Ahn 2003; Dite 2007; Dotis 2014; Espino Hernandez 2012; Garcia‐Aparicio 2013; Garin 2006; Gucuk 2013; Habeeb Abid 2015; Holland 1982; Kojima 2012; Mohseni 2013; Moore 2014; Morris 1991; Nordenstrom 2016; Oswald 2002; Reddy 1997; Roussey‐Kesler 2008; Takvani 2015).

    Incomplete outcome data

    Fourteen studies accounted for all study participants in the analysis and report, giving them a low risk of bias (Craig 2002; Dite 2007; Hari 2015; Holland 1982; IRS EUR 1981‐2003; Lee 2007a; Lee 2015; Mohseni 2013; Pennesi 2008; PRIVENT 2009; Reddy 1997; RIVUR 2008; Roussey‐Kesler 2008; Swedish Reflux Trial 2010), 11 studies were classified as high risk of bias (BIRSG 1983; Capozza 2002; Garcia‐Aparicio 2013; Garin 2006; Habeeb Abid 2015; Kojima 2012; Montini 2008; Moore 2014; Morris 1991; Nordenstrom 2016; Scott 1968). In nine studies it was unclear how many participants were included in the analyses (Ahn 2003; Dotis 2014; Espino Hernandez 2012; Frey 1997; Gucuk 2013; IRS USA 1992; Oswald 2002; Smellie 2001; Takvani 2015), usually because denominators were not reported.

    Selective reporting

    Twelve studies reported the most clinically appropriate outcomes and were considered at low risk of bias (Craig 2002; Hari 2015; IRS EUR 1981‐2003; Lee 2007a; Lee 2015; Mohseni 2013; Montini 2008; Nordenstrom 2016; Pennesi 2008; PRIVENT 2009; RIVUR 2008; Roussey‐Kesler 2008), Thirteen studies reported only surrogate or not the most clinically relevant outcomes such as resolution of VUR and positive urine culture, and were considered at high risk of bias (Ahn 2003; BIRSG 1983; Dotis 2014; Espino Hernandez 2012; Frey 1997; Garcia‐Aparicio 2013; Garin 2006; Gucuk 2013; Habeeb Abid 2015; Moore 2014; Morris 1991; Scott 1968; Takvani 2015). In nine studies details on outcomes were ambiguous or poorly detailed meaning there was an unclear risk of reporting bias (Capozza 2002; Dite 2007; Holland 1982; IRS USA 1992; Kojima 2012; Oswald 2002; Smellie 2001; Swedish Reflux Trial 2010).

    Other potential sources of bias

    For many studies it was difficult to discern who the children were and how many were reviewed for possible inclusion in the study protocol, thereby largely limiting the ability to evaluate the extent of selection bias. Seven studies were considered at low risk of bias from other sources because patients and methods were well detailed and comprehensive (Capozza 2002; Craig 2002; Hari 2015; IRS EUR 1981‐2003; Lee 2007a; PRIVENT 2009; RIVUR 2008). Four studies were considered at high risk of bias from other sources, primarily from poorly reported details on how participants were selected (Holland 1982; Mohseni 2013; Scott 1968; Swedish Reflux Trial 2010), while in 23 studies it was difficult to determine other potential biases (Ahn 2003; BIRSG 1983; Dite 2007; Dotis 2014; Espino Hernandez 2012; Frey 1997; Garcia‐Aparicio 2013; Garin 2006; Gucuk 2013; Habeeb Abid 2015; IRS USA 1992; Kojima 2012; Lee 2015; Montini 2008; Moore 2014; Morris 1991; Nordenstrom 2016; Oswald 2002; Pennesi 2008; Reddy 1997; Roussey‐Kesler 2008; Smellie 2001; Takvani 2015).

    Effects of interventions

    See: Summary of findings for the main comparison Antibiotic prophylaxis versus surveillance or no treatment for primary vesicoureteric reflux; Summary of findings 2 Surgical reimplantation of ureters plus antibiotics versus antibiotics alone for primary vesicoureteric reflux; Summary of findings 3 Endoscopic injection treatment versus antibiotics alone for primary vesicoureteric reflux; Summary of findings 4 Macroplastique versus dextranomer/hyaluronic acid polymer (Deflux) to correct vesicoureteric reflux; Summary of findings 5 Probiotics versus antibiotic prophylaxis for primary vesicoureteric reflux

    Antibiotic prophylaxis versus surveillance or no treatment

    The data were analysed using a random and a fixed effects model, without there being an appreciable difference between the summary estimates. Results are presented using the random effects model. See summary of findings Table for the main comparison.

    Urinary tract infection
    Symptomatic and febrile UTI

    Of the 12 studies that compared antibiotic prophylaxis with placebo or no treatment, nine reported repeat symptomatic UTI as an outcome and allowed distinction of febrile UTI as a separate entity. One and two year incidence of symptomatic UTI varied from 11% to 36% in the group treated with antibiotics and 7% to 58% in the placebo/no treatment groups. The point estimate for overall effect suggested antibiotic prophylaxis may slightly reduce the risk of repeat symptomatic UTI but the wide confidence interval, includes the point of no difference between the treatment groups indicating that antibiotic prophylaxis compared with placebo/no treatment may make little or no difference to the risk of repeat symptomatic UTI (Analysis 1.1.1 (9 studies, 1667 children): RR 0.77, 95% CI 0.54 to 1.09; I2 = 59%; low certainty evidence). Individual studies varied widely in results creating large inconsistencies and study designs were often suboptimal leading to a conclusion of low quality evidence and considerable uncertainty in findings. Similarly for the outcome of febrile UTI by one to two years of follow‐up, antibiotic prophylaxis compared with placebo/no treatment may make little or no difference to the outcome of febrile UTI (Analysis 1.1.2 (9 studies, 1667 children): RR 0.83, 95% CI 0.56 to 1.21I2 = 51%; low certainty evidence). The individual studies were inconsistent and contained considerable bias leading to the assessment of low certainty evidence.

    Two studies (Pennesi 2008; Swedish Reflux Trial 2010) reported outcome data within study arms and separate for girls and boys (Analysis 1.14) and point estimates suggested that in boys, risk of recurrence of febrile UTI was similar whether on antibiotics or with no treatment (RR 1.26, 95% CI 0.53 to 2.99; I2 = 0%). In girls the point estimate suggested a lower risk for recurrence for those on antibiotic treatment than with no treatment (RR 0.63, 95% CI 0.17 to 2.33; I2 = 86%). However both estimates included the point of no difference because sample size was small and events not very common, leading to a lack of precision.

    For these outcomes, there was a large amount of unexplained heterogeneity among studies. We could not identify systematic differences in allocation mechanism, blinding or participant characteristics that explained the heterogeneity. Three studies were rated as low risk of bias across all quality assessment fields (Hari 2015; PRIVENT 2009; RIVUR 2008) and while two studies were reasonably similar in their point estimates (PRIVENT 2009: RR 0.66 95% CI 0.35 to 1.24; RIVUR 2008: RR 0.55 95% CI 0.38 to 0.78), Hari 2015 was very different (RR 3.26, 95% CI 0.96 to 11.10). Therefore we concluded that in this subgroup of studies, antibiotic prophylaxis compared with placebo probably leads to little or no difference in the risk of repeat UTI (moderate certainty evidence). An explanation might be that of a chance affect in a small sample size; Hari 2015 included only 93 children while RIVUR 2008 and PRIVENT 2009 included 607 and 243 children with VUR, respectively. (Analysis 1.1.3).

    Repeat positive urine culture

    In seven studies involving 729 children, the outcome of repeat positive urine culture was reported for urine samples taken in asymptomatic subjects (Craig 2002; Garin 2006; Hari 2015, Montini 2008; Pennesi 2008; Reddy 1997; Roussey‐Kesler 2008). The analysis showed a slightly reduced risk of repeat positive urine culture in children taking antibiotics compared to those on placebo/no treatment (Analysis 1.1.4 (7 studies, 729 participants) RR 0.80, 95% CI 0.63 to 1.02; I2 = 0%). However the confidence interval include the point of no difference so that antibiotic prophylaxis compared with no antibiotics may be little or no difference to the outcome of positive urine culture (low certainty evidence). In addition to comparing a daily antibiotic regimen with surveillance, Reddy 1997 introduced an extra treatment arm to compare intermittent treatment three times/week, with no treatment. In the group treated with intermittent antibiotics 2/14 participants (14%) had a repeat positive urine culture and in the no‐treatment group 5/16 patients experienced a repeat positive urine culture (31%) (Analysis 1.1.5 (1 study, 30 children): RR 0.46, 95% CI 0.10 to 2.00).

    Renal parenchymal abnormality

    In eight studies, the acquisition of new renal abnormalities was evaluated by comparing DMSA scans, taken both at study commencement and completion of follow‐up (Craig 2002; Espino Hernandez 2012; Hari 2015, Montini 2008; Pennesi 2008; PRIVENT 2009; RIVUR 2008; Swedish Reflux Trial 2010). Three studies had no events in either group and hence did not contribute data to the analyses (Craig 2002; Espino Hernandez 2012; Pennesi 2008). Overall antibiotic prophylaxis compared with placebo/no treatment may make little or no difference to the risk of new renal abnormalities (Analysis 1.4.1 (8 studies, 1503 children): RR 0.73, 95% CI 0.33 to 1.61; I2 = 24%), the risk of deterioration of existing renal abnormalities (Analysis 1.4.2 (3 studies, 446 children): RR 0.68, 95% CI 0.27 to 1.73; I2 = 0%), or total renal abnormalities (Analysis 1.4.3 (7 studies, 1288 participants): RR 0.83, 95% CI 0.42 to 1.62; I2 = 42%; low certainty evidence).

    The study comparing intermittent with continuous prophylaxis (Reddy 1997) showed a very imprecise estimate of the risk of renal parenchymal injury between the two treatments with the effect ranging from a possible 98% reduction to over 8‐fold greater risk (Analysis 1.4.5 (1 study, 30 children): RR 0.38, 95% CI 0.02 to 8.59).

    Resolution of VUR

    Three studies (Pennesi 2008; Reddy 1997; Swedish Reflux Trial 2010) reported the VUR status after a two year follow‐up. Overall there was little or no difference in the number of children with persisting VUR (Analysis 1.5 (3 studies, 262 children): RR 1.46, 95% CI 0.71 to 2.99; I2 = 0%; low certainty evidence).

    Adverse events

    Five studies reported adverse effects and the findings were very different for each study (Garin 2006; Hari 2015, Montini 2008; PRIVENT 2009, RIVUR 2008) (Analysis 1.6). Antibiotic prophylaxis compared with placebo/no treatment may make little or no difference to the number of adverse effects reported (Analysis 1.6 (4 studies, 1056 children): RR 0.94, 95% CI 0.81 to 1.08; I2 = 0%; moderate certainty evidence).

    • Garin 2006 explicitly stated 'no reported side effects associated with the use of urinary antibiotic prophylaxis'.

    • Hari 2015 reported 12 and 11 adverse events in the antibiotic and placebo groups respectively

    • PRIVENT 2009 reported two participants developed thrush while on antibiotics and five developed a rash while on placebo.

    • Montini 2008 reported 25 minor adverse events (out of 211 participants), mainly vomiting or gastro‐intestinal intolerance. These data however included patients without VUR and were not reported per treatment group.

    • RIVUR 2008 reported similar frequencies of adverse events across the treatment groups with 153 children in the antibiotic and 165 children in the placebo groups experiencing one or more events.

    Microbial resistance

    Six studies described bacterial resistance to the prophylactic drug in subsequent symptomatic UTIs (Hari 2015, Pennesi 2008; PRIVENT 2009; RIVUR 2008, Roussey‐Kesler 2008; Swedish Reflux Trial 2010). Overall the estimated risk of prophylactic drug resistance in a repeat symptomatic UTI was almost three times higher for children who received antibiotics compared to those on placebo or no treatment (Analysis 1.7.1 (6 studies, 259 urine cultures): RR 2.72, 95% CI 1.85 to 4.00; I2 = 24%; moderate certainty evidence). Assessment of these studies showed there were some reported design features and led to the conclusion that antibiotic prophylaxis compared with placebo/no treatment probably increases the risk of drug resistance. In Garin 2006, all of the seven pyelonephritis cases in children given antibiotics were caused by a resistant micro‐organism but authors did not report whether the single case of pyelonephritis in the placebo group was caused by a bacteria that was sensitive or resistant to commonly used antibiotics.

    Other outcomes

    One small study (46 children), only published in abstract form, reported on DTPA measured GFR, and renal growth at the end of a three year follow‐up period (Craig 2002). Results were only reported as means, but standard deviations could be derived from the accompanying P value. At thee year follow‐up there was little or no difference in GFR (Analysis 1.8 (1 study, 41 children): MD ‐11.00 mL/min/1.73 m2, 95% CI ‐31.53 to 9.53) or in renal growth (Analysis 1.9 (1 study, 41 children): MD 0.04 cm, 95% CI ‐0.04 to 0.12).

    The outcomes of ESKD and hypertension were not reported.

    Surgical reimplantation of ureters plus antibiotics versus antibiotics alone

    There was no appreciable difference between the summary estimates using random and fixed effects models. There were insufficient studies to explore potential effect modification using subgroup analysis or meta‐regression. See summary of findings Table 2.

    Urinary tract infection
    Symptomatic and febrile UTI

    Symptomatic UTI was reported in only one surgical study with the finding of little or no difference in risk between the two treatment groups, at four to five (moderate certainty evidence), and five to 10 years. Febrile UTI was reported in both arms of the international reflux study (IRS EUR 1981‐2003, IRS USA 1992); at five years the risk of repeat febrile UTI was 57% lower in the surgical group (Analysis 2.1.4 (2 studies, 429 participants): RR 0.43 95% CI 0.27 to 0.70; I2 = 0%). The consistency in these two studies and precision of the estimates suggested surgical correction with antibiotic prophylaxis compared with antibiotic prophylaxis probably reduces the risk of febrile UTI (moderate certainty evidence). Only the European arm reported febrile UTI at five to 10 years and after 10 years.

    Repeat positive urine culture

    Repeat positive urine culture was reported in three studies (IRS EUR 1981‐2003; IRS USA 1992; Smellie 2001) and the risk estimate showed little or no difference between the treatment groups. (Analysis 2.1.7 (3 studies, 479 participants): RR 0.99 95% CI 0.79 to 1.26; I2 = 0%; moderate certainty evidence).

    Renal parenchymal abnormality

    Renal parenchymal abnormalities were reported in five studies (BIRSG 1983; Holland 1982; IRS EUR 1981‐2003; IRS USA 1992; Smellie 2001) at varying time points. The frequency of renal parenchymal abnormality (scars and renal parenchymal thinning) on IVP at study entry was 56% to 100% with little or no difference between children receiving antibiotic prophylaxis alone and those treated with surgery plus antibiotics. Surgical correction + antibiotic prophylaxis compared with antibiotic prophylaxis probably makes little or no difference to the number of children developing a new renal parenchymal abnormality, either at two years (Analysis 2.2.1 (2 studies, 171 children): RR 1.06, 95% CI 0.33 to 3.42) or at four to five years (Analysis 2.2.2 (4 studies, 572 children): RR 1.09, 95% CI 0.79 to 1.49; moderate certainty evidence). The risk of progression of an existing abnormality was also similar both at two years (Analysis 2.2.3 (1 study, 10 children): RR 7.00, 95% CI 0.45 to 108.26) and at four to five years (Analysis 2.2.4 (3 studies, 468 children): RR 0.99, 95% CI 0.69 to 1.42). When the development of a new or a progressive abnormality were considered as a single outcome at four to five years, there was little or no difference between the two groups (Analysis 2.2.6 (3 studies, 468 children): RR 1.05, 95% CI 0.85 to 1.29).

    The European (IRS EUR 1981‐2003) and US arms (IRS USA 1992) of the International Reflux Study differentiated renal scarring and renal parenchymal thinning on IVP. Surgical correction + antibiotic prophylaxis with antibiotic prophylaxis probably makes little or no difference to the number of patients with renal scars on IVP at zero to five years (Analysis 2.3.1 (2 studies, 418 children): RR 1.28, 95% CI 0.84 to 1.94), at five to 10 years (Analysis 2.3.2 (1 study, 223 children): RR 1.03, 95% CI 0.07 to 16.22) or zero to 10 years in children followed for 10 years in the European arm of the International Reflux Study (Analysis 2.3.3 (1 study, 223 children): RR 1.03, 95% CI 0.53 to 2.00). All risk estimates were fairly imprecise with large confidence intervals that included the point of no affect. In the IRS EUR 1981‐2003, renal scarring on IVP was present at entry in 49% of the 306 children originally treated and in 51% of 223 children studied by IVP at 10 years. During the first five years of follow‐up, 40 children (surgery plus antibiotic group (21); antibiotic group (19)) developed new scars. Of these, 28 were among the 223 followed radiologically at 10 years. Only two more children, one from each therapy group, developed new scars between five and 10 years.

    When the data were examined according to the total number of kidneys, at two years of follow‐up, Surgical correction + antibiotic prophylaxis with antibiotic prophylaxis probably makes little or no difference to the number of new abnormalities at 2 years (Analysis 2.6.1 (2 studies, 235 children): RR 1.03, 95% CI 0.31 to 3.37), progressive abnormalities (Analysis 2.6.2 (2 studies, 235 children): RR 1.56, 95% CI 0.24 to 10.08) or total renal parenchymal abnormalities (Analysis 2.6.3 (2 studies, 235 children): RR 1.54, 95% CI 0.24 to 9.95) or at 5 years for new abnormalities (Analysis 2.6.4 (2 studies, 319 children): RR 0.85, 95% CI 0.24 to 3.09), progression in abnormality (Analysis 2.6.5 (2 studies, 319 children): RR 0.84, 95% CI 0.50 to 1.41) or total abnormality (Analysis 2.6.6 (2 studies, 319 children): RR 0.84, 95% CI 0.53 to 1.34). All confidence intervals were wide showing imprecision in the estimate and included the point of no effect.

    One study evaluated renal parenchymal abnormality with DMSA scan (IRS EUR 1981‐2003); 97% of children had a scintigraphy performed at five years and 73% of children at 10 years. Parenchymal abnormalities were present in 83% of children at study entry. Relative to the antibiotics‐only group, in the surgical plus antibiotic treatment group there was probably little or no increased risk of new or progressive DMSA scan abnormalities (Analysis 2.5.2 (1 study, 287 children): RR 0.97, 95% CI 0.58 to 1.62) or of deterioration in DMSA scan appearance between five to 10 years (Analysis 2.5.3 (1 study, 216 children): RR 0.71, 95% CI 0.31 to 1.58). All confidence intervals included the point of no effect.

    Renal growth was evaluated in four studies (BIRSG 1983; IRS EUR 1981‐2003; IRS USA 1992; Smellie 2001) at two to 10 years by measurements of changes in renal length standard deviation score (SDS) (3 studies, 510 children) or renal area (1 study, 82 children) on IVP. No real differences between groups were found at any time point or in any age group. Combining data in meta‐analysis was not possible because of differences in reporting.

    ESKD and hypertension

    The two outcomes of greatest clinical importance, ESKD and hypertension, were reported in three studies (BIRSG 1983; IRS EUR 1981‐2003; Smellie 2001). Six children developed ESKD and 14 developed hypertension during follow‐up. It is uncertain whether surgical correction plus antibiotics compared with antibiotics alone reduced the risk for ESKD at five years (Analysis 2.7.1 (2 studies, 154 children): RR 1.07, 95% CI 0.23 to 5.04; I2 = 0%; very low certainty evidence) or of hypertension overall (Analysis 2.7.2 (2 studies, 154 children): RR 0.93, 95% CI 0.25 to 3.42; I2 = 13%; very low certainty evidence), or for hypertension at 10 years (Analysis 2.7.3 (1 study, 252 children): RR 0.15, 95% CI 0.01 to 2.78). Studies were small and imprecise and all confidence intervals were wide and crossed the point of no effect.

    GFR

    Four studies (BIRSG 1983; IRS EUR 1981‐2003; Morris 1991; Smellie 2001) reported on GFR but these were unable to be combined because of insufficiently reported point estimate and variance data. Individually, no study reported any differences between groups. Data from IRS EUR 1981‐2003 showed no differences in GFR measured by the Schwartz formula at study entry (Analysis 2.8.1), at five years (Analysis 2.8.2) and at 10 years (Analysis 2.8.3).

    Height

    Growth was investigated in IRS EUR 1981‐2003. There was no difference in height SDS at study entry (Analysis 2.9.1) or at 10 years (Analysis 2.9.2).

    Correction of VUR

    Resolution of VUR was an outcome described in five studies (BIRSG 1983; IRS EUR 1981‐2003; IRS USA 1992; Smellie 2001; Scott 1968;). We could not combine individual study data for the surgical studies because of differences in reporting practices (patients and ureters), not all patients having had follow‐up VCUGs and missing data. In four studies (BIRSG 1983; IRS EUR 1981‐2003; IRS USA 1992; Smellie 2001) the postoperative resolution rate at four to five years for ureters was 93% to 99%. Over a follow‐up period of three to five years, 16% to 49% of patients had spontaneous resolution of VUR (BIRSG 1983; IRS EUR 1981‐2003; IRS USA 1992; Smellie 2001; Scott 1968). In IRS EUR 1981‐2003, 130/155 children in the antibiotics‐only group had persisting VUR at five years though in 50 other children VUR grade had diminished. Among 102 children undergoing voiding VCUGs at 10 years, VUR was still present in 27 children (22 with grade IV and five with grade III). In Scott 1968, 6/31 had persistent VUR three years postoperatively (very low certainty evidence) and 4/31 had successful operations, but developed VUR in the opposite ureter at a later date.

    Adverse events

    Adverse events for either group were generally not well reported. Postoperative obstruction to the urinary tract occurred in 7% of children (10/151) in the IRS EUR 1981‐2003 study. The BIRSG 1983 study stated that no cases of postoperative obstruction were found after five years. The authors did report six other adverse events. One boy had transient ureteral and renal pelvic dilatation on ultrasound at one month, one boy developed urine retention after endoscopic injection, and one boy aspirated during anaesthesia and required overnight observation in the intensive care unit. One girl suffered abdominal pain with pelvic dilatation and decreasing kidney split function. The authors stated this resulted from a crossing vessel at the pelviureteral junction and was not related to the intervention. Finally, in one boy a fibrous narrowing of the bulbar urethra without obstruction was detected during the first endoscopic procedure. A weakening urine stream and obstructive flow curve pattern led to repeat endoscopic investigation, which revealed deterioration of bulbar narrowing. Ultimately internal urethrotomy was done. No other study referred to obstruction. No other adverse outcomes of surgery were reported.

    No study reported on whether bacterial resistance developed to the prophylactic drug in subsequent symptomatic UTIs

    Surgical reimplantation type 1 versus surgical reimplantation type 2

    One study of 30 children (Kojima 2012) compared surgical reimplantation‐advancement technique with surgical reimplantation‐no advancement technique and reported the outcomes repeat positive urine culture, persistent VUR and perioperative complications. Little or no differences were seen in any outcomes (Analysis 3.1; Analysis 3.2; Analysis 3.3).

    Endoscopic injection treatment with/without antibiotics versus antibiotics alone

    See summary of findings Table 3.

    Urinary tract infection
    Symptomatic and febrile UTI

    Three studies (Dite 2007; Nordenstrom 2016; Swedish Reflux Trial 2010) compared endoscopic injection with antibiotic prophylaxis and reported the outcomes of repeat symptomatic UTI and febrile UTI. Compared with antibiotics alone, endoscopic correction of VUR may lead to little or no reduction in the risk of symptomatic UTI (Analysis 4.1.1 (3 studies, 254 participants): RR 0.80, 95% CI 0.37 to 1.75; I2 = 58%; low certainty evidence) and in the risk of febrile UTI (Analysis 4.1.2 (3 studies, 254 participants): RR 0.74 95% CI 0.31 to 1.78; I2 = 58%; low certainty evidence). The three studies included only 254 children and may reflect chance events. Assessment of these studies showed many study design fields of unclear or high bias and they were small studies with few events and large imprecision.

    Repeat positive urine culture

    One study (Capozza 2002), involving 60 children, reported the outcome of repeat positive urine culture with a very imprecise estimate that cannot be used to guide clinical decisions (Analysis 4.1.3 (1 study, 60 participants) RR 7.15 95% CI 0.42 to 121.04; very low certainty evidence).

    Renal parenchymal abnormality

    Two studies (Nordenstrom 2016; Swedish Reflux Trial 2010) reported the outcome of renal parenchymal defects on DMSA scan. Compared with antibiotic prophylaxis, endoscopic correction of VUR may make little or no difference to the number of children with new or deteriorating renal damage on DMSA scan (Analysis 4.2.1 (2 studies, 208 participants): RR 1.20, 95% CI 0.36 to 3.96; I2 = 45%; low certainty evidence). The inconsistency, bias and small sample size with few events in these studies leads to an assessment of low certainty evidence. One study (Capozza 2002) measured renal damage using ultrasound and reported a very imprecise estimate of treatment effect (Analysis 4.3.1 (1 study, 81 participants: RR 0.34 95% CI 0.04, 3.31) for new renal parenchymal defects

    Correction of VUR

    Compared with antibiotics alone, more children in the endoscopic group may have full resolution of VUR after one to two years (Analysis 4.4.1 (2 studies, 164 children): RR 2.69, 95% CI 1.57 to 4.63) and improvement in VUR grade (Analysis 4.4.2 (3 studies, 238 children): RR 2.01 95% CI 1.51 to 2.68; I2 = 0%; low certainty evidence). Assessment of these studies showed many study design fields with high or unclear levels of bias and the studies were small and imprecise, leading to the conclusion this is low certainty evidence

    Microbial resistance to the prophylactic drug

    Only Swedish Reflux Trial 2010 reported microbial resistance to the treatment antibiotic and showed little or no difference between the groups in the number of UTIs caused by pathogens resistant to the antibiotic being used for prophylaxis (Analysis 4.5; RR 0.63 95% CI 0.34 to 1.15; very low certainty evidence), This finding is not surprising given that both groups were taking antibiotics.

    Adverse events

    None of the children treated with endoscopic injection in Swedish Reflux Trial 2010 experienced vesicoureteric obstruction but three experienced post‐operative complications. Three children in the antibiotic group and none in the endoscopic treatment group within the Nordenstrom 2016 study experienced nausea and vomiting while on treatment.

    Other outcomes

    ESKD and hypertension were not reported.

    Endoscopic injection treatment versus no treatment

    Urinary tract infection
    Symptomatic and febrile UTI

    Swedish Reflux Trial 2010 involved three study arms which allows for a comparison between endoscopic injection treatment and no treatment. Compared with no treatment, endoscopic correction of VUR may reduce the risk for symptomatic and febrile UTI (Analysis 5.1. (1 study; 134 participants): RR 0.55 95% CI 0.33 to 0.94 and Analysis 5.2, (1 study, 134 participants): RR 0.52 95% CI 0.30 to 0.89). Since only 134 children were studied this may represent a chance effect.

    Renal parenchymal abnormality

    Swedish Reflux Trial 2010,compared with no treatment, endoscopic correction of VUR may make little of no difference to the risk for renal parenchymal defects (Analysis 5.3 (1 study, 133 participants): RR 0.70, 95% CI 0.3 to 1.6).

    Other outcomes

    Resolution of VUR, ESKD, hypertension, and adverse events were not reported.

    Different materials for subureteric injection to correct VUR

    See summary of findings Table 4.

    Four studies compared two different products for endoscopic injection to correct VUR, Two studies (Moore 2014; Oswald 2002) compared endoscopic subureteric injections of Macroplastique with Deflux but these were dissimilar in that Oswald 2002 compared these in children also taking prophylactic antibiotics. Moore 2014 showed no difference in the number of febrile UTIs across the two treatment groups and Oswald 2002 reported no difference in afebrile UTIs between the two groups. For the outcome of persistent VUR both studies favoured Macroplastique with a 50% reduction in risk of persistent VUR at three months (Analysis 6.1.3 (2 studies, 513 participants): RR 0.50, 95% CI 0.33 to 0.78; I2 = 0%) and a 46% reduction in risk at 12 months (Analysis 6.1.4 (2 studies, 472 participants): RR 0.54 (95% CI 0.35 to 0.83; I2 = 0%). Assessment of these studies found study design fields of unclear or high risk of bias indicating that subureteric injection with Macroplastique compared with dextranomer hyaluronic acid polymer probably reduces the risk for persistent VUR (moderate certainty evidence). Oswald 2002 reported a moderately higher risk of temporary pelvicaliceal dilatation with Macroplastique (Analysis 6.1.5 (114 participants): RR 1.85, 95% CI 1.02 to 3.35; low certainty evidence). Moore 2014 reported three cases of ureteral obstruction in the Macroplastique group compared with two cases in the Deflux group (low certainty evidence). There were four cases of flank pain after injection in the Macroplastique compared with three cases in the Deflux group of Moore 2014 (low certainty evidence).

    No data on renal parenchymal abnormalities were reported.

    One small study of 28 children (Frey 1997) compared endoscopic subureteric injections of different concentrations of GAX 65 and GAX 35. VUR was five times more likely to persist following GAX 35 than GAX 65 injections (Analysis 6.2.1 (28 children): RR 0.21, 95% CI 0.05 to 0.85). The estimated risk of recurrence of VUR between therapies was imprecise (Analysis 6.2.2 (1 study, 28 children): RR 0.30, 95% CI 0.07 to 1.29). No data on UTIs or renal parenchymal abnormalities were reported. This study represents very low certainty evidence.

    Habeeb Abid 2015 compared dextranomer hyaluronic acid polymer with polyacrylate polyalcohol bulking polymer (Vantris). UTIs were not reported. Different bulking agents may lead to little or no difference in risk of repeat positive urine culture, fever, persistence of VUR or ureteral obstruction (Analysis 6.3.1 to Analysis 6.3.4) (low certainty evidence).

    Probiotic versus antibiotic prophylaxis

    See summary of findings Table 5.

    Two studies (Lee 2007a; Lee 2015) compared the potential benefits and harms of probiotic versus antibiotic prophylaxis in single centre studies and included 120 and 128 children respectively. Compared with antibiotic prophylaxis, probiotics may make little or no difference in risk of repeat symptomatic UTI (Analysis 7.1.1 (1 study, 24 children): RR 0.82, 95% CI 0.56 to 1.21) and febrile UTI at one year (Analysis 7.1.2 (1 study, 24 children): RR 0.82, 95% CI 0.37 to 1.83; low certainty evidence). Assessment of these two studies showed there were many study design fields with high or unclear risk of bias, the studies were small and imprecise, leading to the conclusion there is low certainty in this evidence. In Lee 2007a by the end of the one year follow‐up period, 2 of 13 patients in the antibiotics group had experienced a repeat UTI and had developed a new renal scar, versus 1 of 11 in the probiotics group. In Lee 2007a seven symptomatic UTI recurrences (64%) had Escherichia coli identified as the causative organism in the probiotics group versus nine (69%) in the antibiotics group. These data were not available for Lee 2015. Across the two studies, six of the 18 repeat UTIs caused by E.coli in the probiotic group were resistant to trimethoprim‐sulphamethoxazole while 20/20 E. coli infections were resistant to the treatment drug in the antibiotic group (Analysis 7.2 (RR 0.38, 95% CI 0.21 to 0.69)(RR 0.38, 95% CI 0.21 to 0.69; I2 = 0%). Compared with antibiotic prophylaxis, probiotics may make little or no difference to the risk of renal parenchymal abnormality (Analysis 7.3.1 (2 studies, 152 participants): RR 0.69, 95% CI 0.43 to 1.11; I2 = 0%; low certainty evidence). These studies do not provide evidence of sufficient certainty to support clinical decisions on the efficacy of probiotics to prevent UTI in children.

    A single study of 85 children compared probiotics plus antibiotics with antibiotics alone (Mohseni 2013). No difference between treatment groups was seen for the outcomes repeat febrile UTI, repeat positive urine culture, new DMSA changes, microbial resistance and adverse effects (Analysis 7.4).

    ESKD, hypertension, resolution of VUR, and adverse events were not reported.

    Other Interventions

    Surgical reimplantation versus endoscopic treatment

    A single small scale study (Garcia‐Aparicio 2013) compared surgical reimplantation (Cohens technique) with endoscopic injection of dextranomer hyaluronic acid polymer in 41 children. Compared with endoscopic treatment, surgical implantation may make little or no difference in outcomes of repeat positive urine culture, VUR resolution or complications of the procedures were seen between the surgical and endoscopic treatment groups (Analysis 8.1) (low certainty evidence).

    Cranberry products

    A study of 76 children (Dotis 2014) compared cranberry capsules with no treatment and found repeat positive urine culture was more frequent in the no treatment arm (Analysis 8.2 (1 study, 76 participants): RR 0.29 95% CI 0.14 to 0.59). It is uncertain whether cranberry capsules compared with no treatment prevents UTI since the certainty of the evidence is very low.

    Circumcision

    Gucuk 2013 compared circumcision plus antibiotics to antibiotics alone in 91 boys with VUR. Repeat positive urine culture was less frequent in the circumcision group (Analysis 8.3.2; (91 participants): RR 0.28 95% CI 0.12 to 0.70) but symptomatic UTI and DMSA changes showed no differences across treatment groups (Analysis 8.3.1; Analysis 8.3.3). From this single RCT, it remains uncertain whether circumcision plus antibiotics prevents UTI since the certainty of this evidence is very low (very low certainty evidence).

    Oxybutynin

    Ahn 2003 compared the anticholinergic, Oxybutynin, with placebo for the outcome resolution of VUR at 12 months. 38/56 (67.9%) children treated with oxybutynin had resolution or improvement of their VUR grade while 57/93 (61.3%) children in the placebo group showed an improved or resolved VUR grade after 12 months (Analysis 8.4). Oxybutynin compared with placebo may make little or no difference to the improvement in VUR (low certainty evidence).

    Discussion

    Summary of main results

    The benefits and harms of interventions for primary VUR were assessed in 34 studies involving 4001 children.

    Antibiotic prophylaxis versus surveillance/no treatment

    Twelve studies comparing long‐term low‐dose antibiotic prophylaxis with placebo or no treatment were identified. Although the pooled estimate of risk of repeat symptomatic and febrile UTI favoured antibiotic treatment, precision was poor and included no difference between treatment groups. Overall, long‐term low‐dose antibiotic prophylaxis may make little or no difference to the number of children who experience repeat symptomatic or febrile UTI (low certainty evidence) or to the number of children, developing new or progressive renal damage compared with placebo or no treatment (low certainty evidence) (summary of findings Table for the main comparison). Three studies were at low risk of bias across all study design fields and when only these three studies were considered, antibiotic prophylaxis made little or no difference to the likelihood of further UTIs (moderate certainty evidence) (summary of findings Table for the main comparison). Side effects of the preventive treatment were minor and infrequent but poorly reported (low certainty evidence) (summary of findings Table for the main comparison.) Little data were provided as to how side‐effects had affected adherence. Reported compliance rates varied between 70% and 100%, but they were inconsistently measured. Since previous studies have shown poor compliance for daily antibiotic regimens for VUR (Cohen 2005; Greenfield 1997), it raises the question whether antibiotics were inherently ineffective or were not being used as prescribed. Treating VUR patients with long‐term low‐dose antibiotics probably increases the risk of microbial resistance against the prophylactic drug in breakthrough infections (moderate certainty evidence) (summary of findings Table for the main comparison).

    Surgical reimplantation of ureters plus antibiotics (1 to 24 months) versus antibiotics alone

    Only the European arm of the IRS study evaluated the differential risk of any symptomatic UTI between medical and surgical treatment and found that by four to five years, there was little or no difference in symptomatic UTI. Both the European and the American arms of the IRS study however, investigated the risk of febrile UTI and found a significant benefit for those children who underwent surgical VUR correction. Assuming a baseline risk of 22% of developing febrile UTI when on antibiotics alone the estimated risk translates into a risk difference of 13% so that eight patients need surgery to prevent one extra febrile UTI over five years. T. Further analysis at 10 years confirmed these results. It supports the idea that although surgery might not provide an added benefit over antibiotic prophylaxis in preventing symptomatic lower UTI, it might keep the infection from spreading to the upper tract, and ultimately prevent subsequent renal damage. No evidence was found to corroborate this theory however, since the risk of developing new or progressive renal damage at five and 10 years was no different between the treatment groups. Although no differences between treatment groups were demonstrated for hypertension or end stage kidney disease, it remains uncertain whether surgical correction of VUR influences the risk of hypertension and CKD because the certainty of this evidence is very low (summary of findings Table 2).

    Potential benefits of surgery need to be weighed against its potential adverse effects. Whereas the Birmingham Reflux Study stated that no cases of postoperative obstruction were found after five years, they occurred in 7% of children (10/151) in the European arm of the International Reflux Study, corresponding to one every 14 to 15 patients undergoing the procedure.

    Endoscopic injection treatment for VUR correction

    If VUR correction were beneficial, endoscopic subureteric injection of various materials could offer an alternative method to open surgery for correcting VUR. Eight studies included in this review used endoscopic injection in at least one study group, and these have demonstrated VUR correction rates of 70% to 90%. However when compared with long‐term low‐dose antibiotic prophylaxis alone, endoscopic correction with or without antibiotics may make little or no difference to the likelihood of either symptomatic, febrile UTI or progressive renal damage. Results were derived from three small studies with only 254 children leading to low certainty evidence (summary of findings Table 3). A single small study (Swedish Reflux Trial 2010) found that fewer children following endoscopic correction of VUR developed UTI compared to no treatment.

    Four studies in this review directly compared two different materials with each other, with two suggesting that Macroplastique is superior to dextranomer/hyaluronic acid polymer for correcting reflux. However the quality, size and consistency of findings is inadequate for confident conclusions (low certainty evidence) (summary of findings Table 4).

    Other interventions

    Probiotic treatment may make little or no difference to the risk of symptomatic UTI or renal damage detected by DMSA scan (low certainty evidence) (summary of findings Table 5). Cranberry capsules, circumcision and oxybutynin were trialled in single, small studies with each study result favouring the intervention but with limited confidence due to imprecision from small sample sizes with infrequent events, and sources of bias from sub‐optimal study designs.

    Overall completeness and applicability of evidence

    Children with grade V reflux are generally viewed as having the highest risk of developing renal damage after pyelonephritis. However in the 12 studies of low‐dose antibiotic treatment compared with placebo or no treatment, only three included children with grade V reflux and only PRIVENT 2009 specified the number of children (5) with grade V reflux. Most surgical reimplantation studies included participants with VUR grades II, III and IV and children with grade V VUR were excluded. Hence we cannot extrapolate the results from this review to children with VUR grade V. A randomised comparison between antibiotic treatment and surgical reimplantation alone has not been performed since in all studies, antibiotics were given to children undergoing surgery. Very few studies reported data for analysis of treatment effect within the genders and laterality of VUR, hence no conclusions could be drawn. The few small studies comparing endoscopic injection treatment of VUR with antibiotic prophylaxis are insufficient to determine whether there are real benefits for endoscopic correction over antibiotic prophylaxis or no treatment. Further studies are required to determine if probiotics or other interventions have any role in preventing UTI in children with VUR.

    Quality of the evidence

    The quality of conduct and reporting of these studies was variable, with many studies omitting crucial methodological information used to assess the risk of bias. Only four of the 34 studies were considered at low risk of bias across all fields of study quality (Craig 2002; Hari 2015; PRIVENT 2009; RIVUR 2008). The majority of studies had many areas of uncertainty in the risk of bias fields, reflecting missing detail rather than stated poor design.

    The overall certainty of the evidence using GRADE was considered to be low in most analyses. Only two analyses were considered to have moderate overall certainty of the evidence.

    The effect estimate of incremental benefit of surgical reimplantation was based on only two studies that included 429 patients in the analysis. Given the nature of the intervention, it was not possible to blind participants or health care providers. Unblinded studies tend to report an overestimation of treatment effects and as such bias might have played a part in producing the difference in risk of febrile UTI in favour of surgical management.

    Potential biases in the review process

    A comprehensive search of the Cochrane Kidney and Transplant’s Specialised Register was performed for this review thus reducing the possibility that potential eligible studies were omitted from the review. Eligible studies published after the last search date or published in congress proceedings not routinely searched could have been missed. Authors of this review are also authors of an included study (PRIVENT 2009) and may have judged that study more favourably. To alleviate this concern, an independent researcher extracted risk of bias data from PRIVENT 2009 and this was incorporated into the review.

    Agreements and disagreements with other studies or reviews

    For over five decades, scientific published work has suggested the existence of a link between recurrent UTI, VUR, and renal scarring (Olbing 2003; Smellie 1975; Smellie 1994; Smellie 1998). VUR has been thought to facilitate the involvement of the upper urinary tract during UTI by allowing retrograde passage of infected urine to the ureter. Subsequently all interventions have been targeted at preventing UTI‐induced damage to the kidney. Two earlier versions of this review (Hodson 2007; Wheeler 2004) were not able to provide evidence as to whether the common practice of diagnosing and treating children with VUR conferred important health benefits, since no adequately powered studies had included a no treatment arm. Since then, new studies have compared the administration of antibiotics with placebo or no treatment. Although the addition of these studies produced a risk estimate in favour of long‐term low‐dose antibiotics for preventing repeat symptomatic UTI, the imprecision of the estimate means there may be no difference in risk of repeat UTI between children taking antibiotics and those not treated.

    In this review, we have highlighted symptomatic and febrile UTI as more relevant primary end points than positive urine cultures.
